case_name: Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation v. Respondents

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 281 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 281 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 26, 1968 of the Kerala High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 113 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal against Kerala High Court judgment dated June 26, 1968 in Criminal Appeal No. 113 of 1968 confirming acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 26, 1968 of the Kerala High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 113 of 1968. Sreedharan Nambiar, for the appellant. K. Mehta, K. L. Mehta, and K. R. Nagaraja, for the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant is Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Vaidialingam, J.-This appeal, by special leave, by the Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation, is directed against the judgment and order dated June 26, 1968 of the Kerala High Court in 46-I S.C. India/7i Criminal Appeal No. 113 of 1968 companyfirming the acquittal of the respondents of an offence under S. 16 1  a  i  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954  Act No. 37 of 1954   hereinafter to be referred to as the Act .

facts.text: First respondent is Manager and second respondent, his wife, owner and licensee of tea stall at premises No. 4/777 Customs Road, Calicut.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent is the Manager and the second respondent, his wife, are the owner and licencee of a tea stallin the premises No. 4/777 Customs Road, Calicut. They were accused Nos. 1 and 2 respectively.

facts.text: On November 17, 1965 at about 9.45 A.M., Food Inspector purchased 600 grams of sugar for 78 paise from first respondent for analysis from stock kept for preparation of tea.

anchor.surface_text: On November 17, 1965 at about 9.45 A.M., the Food Inspector, Calicut Corporation, purchased from the first respondent 600 grams of sugar for a price of 78 paise ,for analysis from the stock of sugar kept in the premises to be used in the preparation of tea sold to customers in the said tea stall run by the second respondent under the licence issued by the Corporation.

facts.text: Sample of sugar purchased was sampled as per rules in presence of first accused and witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The quantity of sugar so purchased was sampled as per the rules in the presence of the first accused and the witnesses. One portion of the sample was sent to the Public Analyst for analysis.

facts.text: Public Analyst report Ex. P.3 dated December 28, 1965 certified sample contained saccharin equivalent to about seven percent of cane sugar, adulterated.

anchor.surface_text: The Analyst in his report Ex. P. 3 dated December 28, 1965 has certified that the sample companytained artificial sweetner saccharin equivalent to about seven percent of cane sugar and therefore it was adulterated. In fact the analysis is as follows Ash 0.02 per cent Total sugar 96.00 per cent as cane sugar Saccharin 14.0 mgs. per 100 gms.

facts.text: Food Inspector filed complaint on March 21, 1966 against two accused in Court of District Magistrate (Judicial), Calicut.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of this report the Food Inspector filed on March 21, 1966 a companyplaint against the two accused in the Court of the District Magistrate,  Judicial , Calicut.

facts.text: Accused charged under S.16(1)(a)(i) of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act for selling adulterated sugar on November 17, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Both the accused were charged of an offence under s. 16 1  a  i  of the Act for having sold on November 17, 1965 600 gm. of sugar for a price of 78 paise to the Food Inspector from the tea stall and which sugar was found to be adulterated by the Public Analyst.

facts.text: Accused pleaded not guilty and denied selling sugar to Food Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: Both the accused pleaded number guilty and even denied having sold sugar to the Food Inspector.

facts.text: District Magistrate found sugar purchased and sampled in compliance with Act, adulterated, but not kept for sale as such, only for tea preparation; acquitted under s.258 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The learned District Magistrate recorded the following find- ings The sugar is an article of food as defined under s. 2 v  of the Act the Food Inspector purchased sugar from the tea stall of the accused, sampled it then and there and handed over to the first accused. There was a sale as defined in the Act of sugar to the Food Inspector by the first accused the ,purchase and the sampling by the Food Inspector were done in strict companypliance with the provisions of the Act. The report of the Public Analyst establishes that the sugar purchased from ,the tea stall of the accused was adulterated. But in order to hold that the accused have companymitted an offence, it must be established that the accused were selling sugar as such in the tea stall, which is number the fact in this case. On the other hand, the accused were selling tea and the sugar was kept only for the purpose of being mixed with tea which was sold to the ,customers and the Food Inspector has clearly admitted that sugar as such is number in the tea stall of the accused.

facts.text: Kerala High Court agreed with District Magistrate on sale to FI and adulteration, but held sugar not kept for sale as such; confirmed acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The State filed an appeal before the Kerala High Court challenging the acquittal of the respondents. The High Court agreed with the findings of the District Magistrate that there was a sale as defined in the Act of sugar to the Food Inspector by ,the accused on November 17, 1965 and the said article was adulterated as is established by the report of the Public Analyst. The High Court set before it the principle that the prosecution will have to establish, under such circumstances, that the persons from whom the article of food had been purchased are those selling those articles as such. The High Court applied the test to find out whether the respondents are persons selling ,sugar as such and answered the question in the negative.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds sale to Food Inspector constitutes sale under Act, sugar adulterated, respondents technically guilty but acquittal not set aside as test case.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the case on hand, on the finding of the two companyrts the sugar in question has been found to be adulterated. The purchase by the Food Inspector from the accused of sugar for purposes of analysis is a sale under s. 2 13  of the. Act. Section 7 prohibits a person from selling adulterated article of food. Similarly, under s. 16 1  a  i  any person who sells adulterated food companymits an offence and is punishable therein. ... Hence it must be held that the respondents are technically guilty of the offence with which they were charged and they have been wrongly acquitted by the High Court and the District Magistrate. But in view of the fact that the appellant has argued the appeal only as a test case and does number challenge the acquittal of the respondents, we merely set aside the order and judgment of the High Court.

facts.text: Food Inspector admitted sugar not kept for sale as such in tea stall.

anchor.surface_text: the Food Inspector has clearly admitted that sugar as such is number in the tea stall of the accused. Inasmuch as sugar was number kept for sale by the accused, they are number guilty of any offence.

facts.text: Sugar analysis: Ash 0.02 per cent, Total sugar 96.00 per cent as cane sugar, Saccharin 14.0 mgs. per 100 gms.

anchor.surface_text: In fact the analysis is as follows Ash 0.02 per cent Total sugar 96.00 per cent as cane sugar Saccharin 14.0 mgs. per 100 gms.

facts.text: Reference to prior conviction of first accused, but not necessary to refer.

anchor.surface_text: There is a reference to the companyviction of the first accused on prior occasions. It is number necessary for us number to refer it.

facts.text: Supreme Court directed deposit of Rs.1000 on December 12, 1968 for respondents' costs.

anchor.surface_text: We find that on December 12, 1968 when granting special leave this Court had directed the appellant to deposit Rs. 1000/to be used by the respondents for their companyts and liberty has been given to the respondents to withdraw the amount to pay fee to, the companynsel, in case they engage a companynsel.

facts.text: Appellant does not want conviction, only decision on legal point.

anchor.surface_text: Before we proceed to deal with these companytentions with reference to the provisions of the Act and certain decisions placed before us by both the learned companynsel, it is to be recorded that Mr. Nambiar has made it clear that his clients do number want the respondents to be companyvicted, in case his companytentions are accepted.

facts.text: District Magistrate acquitted accused under s.258(1) of Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, both the accused were acquitted ,under s. 258 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Tea stall run by second respondent under licence issued by Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: from the stock of sugar kept in the premises to be used in the preparation of tea sold to customers in the said tea stall run by the second respondent under the licence issued by the Corporation.

issues.text: whether there has been a sale to the Food Inspector under the Act of an article of food which is found to be adulterated such that the accused is guilty of an offence punishable under s. 16(1)(a)(i) read with s. 7 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: To sum up we are in agreement with the decisions reported in Municipal Board, Faizabad v. Lal Chand Surajmal and another 1  and The Public Prosecutor v. Palanisami Nadar 2  to the extent to which they lay down the principle that when there is a sale to the Food Inspector under the Act of an article of food, which is found to be adulterated, the accused will be guilty of an offence punishable under s. 16 1  a  i  read with s. 7 of the Act.

issues.text: whether the article of food which has been purchased by the Food Inspector need have been taken out from a larger quantity intended for sale

anchor.surface_text: We further agree that the article of food which has been purchased by the Food Inspector need not have been taken out from a larger quantity intended for sale.

issues.text: whether the person from whom the article of food has been purchased by the Food Inspector need be a dealer as such in that article

anchor.surface_text: We are also of the opinion that the person from whom the article of food has been purchased by the Food Inspector need not be a dealer as such in that article. We are not inclined to agree with the decisions laying the contrary propositions.

issues.text: whether the expression stored occurring in s. 7 and s. 16 should be interpreted as storage for purposes of sale

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary for us in the case before us to consider whether the expression stored occurring in s. 7 and s. 16 should be interpreted as storage for purposes of sale. The case on hand can be disposed of without deciding that aspect.

issues.text: whether the respondents are persons selling sugar as such

anchor.surface_text: The High Court applied the test to find out whether the respondents are persons selling sugar as such and answered the question in the negative. Agreeing with the findings of the District Magistrate that the sugar in the tea stall of the accused was not kept for sale as such but for being utilised in the preparation of tea

arguments.claim: Accused guilty even if not dealers per Municipal Board Faizabad (milk in tea shop)

anchor.surface_text: In the decision reported in Municipal Board, Faizabad v. Lal Chand Surajmal and another 2  the accused had a shop where tea was sold and for the purpose of preparing tea, they had stored milk which was a necessary ingredient for the preparation of tea. The Food Inspector took a sample of milk from the tea shop and on analysis it was found to be adulterated.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judge held that it is number necessary that the accused should be a dealer in Dahi as such and it is also number necessary that the Dahi sold to the Food Inspector must have been taken out of a larger quantity intended for sale.

arguments.claim: Sale to FI of adulterated article makes guilty per Public Prosecutor v Palanisami Nadar

anchor.surface_text: To a similar effect is the decision of The Public Prosecutor Palanisami Nadar 2  where it was held that when there has been a sale to the Food Inspector for analysis of an article of, food, which, when found to be adulterated, the accused is guilty of an offence.

holdings.text: when there is a sale to the Food Inspector under the Act of an article of food, which is found to be adulterated, the accused will be guilty of an offence punishable under s. 16(1)(a)(i) read with s. 7 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: To sum up we are in agreement with the decisions reported in Municipal Board, Faizabad v. Lal Chand Surajmal and another 1  and The Public Prosecutor v. Palanisami Nadar 2  to the extent to which they lay down the principle that when there is a sale to the Food Inspector under the Act of an article of food, which is found to be adulterated, the accused will be guilty of an offence punishable under s. 16 1  a  i  read with s. 7 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents (Municipal Board Faizabad, Public Prosecutor v Palanisami Nadar); sale for analysis under s.2(xiii) triggers prohibition in s.7 and punishment in s.16(1)(a)(i)

holdings.text: the article of food which has been purchased by the Food Inspector need not have been taken out from a larger quantity intended for sale

anchor.surface_text: We further agree that the article of food which has been purchased by the Food Inspector need not have been taken out from a larger quantity intended for sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with State of Gujarat v Asandas; no such requirement in definition of sale under s.2(xiii)

holdings.text: the person from whom the article of food has been purchased by the Food Inspector need not be a dealer as such in that article

anchor.surface_text: We are also of the opinion that the person from whom the article of food has been purchased by the Food Inspector need not be a dealer as such in that article. We are not inclined to agree with the decisions laying the contrary propositions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects contrary decisions (e.g. Govinda Rao); no such requirement in Act; sale to FI under s.2(xiii) sufficient; distinguishes storage cases

holdings.text: sugar is an article of food under s.2(v) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The sugar which is the commodity before us is food under s. 2 5  of the Act. We have already pointed out that sugar by itself is an article used as food or at any rate it is an article which, ordinarily enters into or is used in the composition or preparation of human food.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies definition in s.2(v): used as food or enters preparation of human food; no controversy

holdings.text: purchase by Food Inspector for analysis is a sale under s.2(xiii) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The purchase by the Food Inspector from the accused of sugar for purposes of analysis is a sale under s. 2 13  of the. Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly includes sale for analysis in definition; follows Mangaldas Raghavji Ruparel

holdings.text: respondents are technically guilty of the offence under s.16(1)(a)(i) r/w s.7 but acquittal not set aside as test case

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the case on hand, on the finding of the two courts the sugar in question has been found to be adulterated. The purchase by the Food Inspector from the accused of sugar for purposes of analysis is a sale under s. 2 13  of the. Act. Section 7 prohibits a person from selling adulterated article of food. Similarly, under s. 16 1  a  i  any person who sells adulterated food commits an offence and is punishable therein. ... Hence it must be held that the respondents are technically guilty of the offence with which they were charged and they have been wrongly acquitted by the High Court and the District Magistrate. But in view of the fact that the appellant has argued the appeal only as a test case and does not challenge the acquittal of the respondents, we merely set aside the order and judgment of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies principles to facts: sale occurred, sugar food and adulterated; lower courts erred but no conviction sought

holdings.text: not necessary to decide if 'stored' in ss.7 and 16 means storage for sale

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary for us in the case before us to consider whether the expression stored occurring in s. 7 and s. 16 should be interpreted as storage for purposes of sale. The case on hand can be disposed of without deciding that aspect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue avoided as case decided on sale, not storage

holdings.text: sections 12 and 14 do not require seller to be dealer as such
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading: s.12 for any purchaser, s.14 for manufacturer/distributor/dealer giving warranty; do not limit offence to dealers

anchor.surface_text: To sum up we are in agreement with the decisions reported in Municipal Board, Faizabad v. Lal Chand Surajmal and another 1  and The Public Prosecutor v. Palanisami Nadar 2  to the extent to which they lay down the principle that when there is a sale to the Food Inspector under the Act of an article of food, which is found to be adulterated, the accused will be guilty of an offence punishable under s. 16 1  a  i  read with s. 7 of the Act.
In the result the judgment and order of the High Court are set aside and the appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: We further agree that the article of food which has been purchased by the Food Inspector need not have been taken out from a larger quantity intended for sale.
In the result the judgment and order of the High Court are set aside and the appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: We are also of the opinion that the person from whom the article of food has been purchased by the Food Inspector need not be a dealer as such in that article. We are not inclined to agree with the decisions laying the contrary propositions.
In the result the judgment and order of the High Court are set aside and the appeal allowed.

edges.explanation: h6 applies and supports the general rule in h1 by finding technical guilt for sale of adulterated food

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the case on hand, on the finding of the two courts the sugar in question has been found to be adulterated. The purchase by the Food Inspector from the accused of sugar for purposes of analysis is a sale under s. 2 13  of the. Act. Section 7 prohibits a person from selling adulterated article of food. Similarly, under s. 16 1  a  i  any person who sells adulterated food commits an offence and is punishable therein. ... Hence it must be held that the respondents are technically guilty of the offence with which they were charged and they have been wrongly acquitted by the High Court and the District Magistrate. But in view of the fact that the appellant has argued the appeal only as a test case and does not challenge the acquittal of the respondents, we merely set aside the order and judgment of the High Court.
In the result the judgment and order of the High Court are set aside and the appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary for us in the case before us to consider whether the expression stored occurring in s. 7 and s. 16 should be interpreted as storage for purposes of sale. The case on hand can be disposed of without deciding that aspect.
In the result the judgment and order of the High Court are set aside and the appeal allowed.
